Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 03:38PM just4ann wrote: Hey ladies.  Just found your thread and wanted to share.  I developed LE shortly following my surgery.  My onc noticed it first.  My surgeon had not even mentioned it which I find so hard to believe especially when approximately 30% of patients that have lymph nodes removed develop LE.  You would think that would be mentioned prior to surgery.  But that's not what I wanted to share.   You know there are so many precautions that we are suppose to follow.  So many in fact that I was skeptical about being so cautious.  I mean, come on, if it were that risky you would think someone would mention it as part of bc awareness.  Anyway, I found out the hard way just how cautious we have to be.  A couple of weeks ago I cut my hand while using a knife to open a package.  Not a bad cut, just let the knife slip a little and poked myself in the palm of my hand.  It hardly even bled.  But I still went overboard on the first aid practices just to be safe.  Well, two days later I woke up with one of my fingers swollen to twice the size and the fingernail greenish yellow.  I immediately went to my PCP and she gave me a shot of antibiotics along with a RX.  She said that anytime I have any type of injury to that arm, especially if the skin is broken, I will more than likely develop an infection and that I should go ahead and call her so I can get started on antibiotics.    I had been wearing a compression sleeve and gauntlet on that arm to keep my swelling down but once I developed the infection I had to quit wearing them.  My hand was swollen just enough to cause them to cut the circulation off.  I called my LE therapist and was told to discontinue the sleeve and gauntlet as well as any massage until the infection was gone.  She said the massage when infection is present is very dangerous.  It can actually cause the infection to spread.  She suggested I just lightly wrap it to control the swelling as much as possible without cutting off circulation to my hand. I just finished my antibiotics on Tuesday and have an appointment with my LE therapist tomorrow.  I will have to go back through the compression wrapping again just to get my arm to the point I can wear my sleeve and gauntlet.  All because of a little prick in the hand.   So please learn from my mistake and don't take all of the precautions too lightly.   -- Ann

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 09:56PM just4ann wrote: Hi everyone.  I am 12 weeks PFC and just wanted to chime in.  I was hopeful that I would see a lot more hair at 12 weeks than I do.  The top of my head is covered with white, kinky fuzz about 1 1/2 inches long.  Okay, covered is not accurate.  I mean the top of my head has hair growing but it is thin and sparse.  Lots of scalp still visible.  The sides and back are just now beginning to pass the stubble stage.  My surgeon, who happened to have gone through chemo herself last year, recommended using a baby hair brush.  She said being bald for so long allows the hair follicles to become clogged.  Using the baby brush will not only help with the clogged follicles but also will stimulate my scalp.  My granddaughter thinks it is great fun to brush my "baby hair" with a baby brush.  She's 3 years old.  She does get a bit frustrated though because its so kinky she can't get it to lay down on top.  The other day she was brushing it and next thing I know she has spit in her hand and rubbed it on the top of my head! I told her to please not do that again.  She said, "Don't worry, I won't.  It doesn't work."
